docs.abstract: Anti-Government demonstrators demanding the resignation of President H. M. Ershad fought with the police today, exploding homemade bombs in the center of Dhaka, the capital. Journalists at the scene said at least 20 people were injured. They said riot-equipped police officers fired rifles in the air and used tear gas and steel-tipped batons to disperse the protesters, numbering about 3,000, mostly students.
docs.lead_paragraph: Anti-Government demonstrators demanding the resignation of President H. M. Ershad fought with the police today, exploding homemade bombs in the center of Dhaka, the capital. Journalists at the scene said at least 20 people were injured. They said riot-equipped police officers fired rifles in the air and used tear gas and steel-tipped batons to disperse the protesters, numbering about 3,000, mostly students.

docs.abstract: LEAD: The Government announced today that it was banning demonstrations outside Parliament, the site of several opposition rallies last year. The decision, which takes effect Wednesday, is apparently meant to thwart a demonstration when Parliament opens its session Thursday.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Government announced today that it was banning demonstrations outside Parliament, the site of several opposition rallies last year. The decision, which takes effect Wednesday, is apparently meant to thwart a demonstration when Parliament opens its session Thursday.

docs.abstract: The police arrested the former Vice President in the Government of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad today after a nine-day search, a news agency reported.   The former official, Moudud Ahmed, a member of General Ershad's inner circle, was found in a friend's home and put under house arrest in his luxurious villa in the Gulshan diplomatic enclave, United Press of Bangladesh reported.
docs.lead_paragraph: The police arrested the former Vice President in the Government of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad today after a nine-day search, a news agency reported.

docs.abstract: After 19 years of independence in which this vulnerable nation has known little else but human tragedy and natural disaster, the capital is alive today with new hopes.    Against long odds and with stunning speed, an eight-day revolution last week not only brought down the eight-year-old military Government of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, but also did it with the decisive support of the army.
docs.lead_paragraph: After 19 years of independence in which this vulnerable nation has known little else but human tragedy and natural disaster, the capital is alive today with new hopes.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

byline.original: By Barbara Crossette, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: Opposition parties nominated the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court today to head a caretaker government, the day after President H. M. Ershad announced his resignation.   The news that General Ershad would step down was greeted with noisy celebrations by thousands of people, many of whom ran from their homes in pajamas to dance in the streets and set off firecrackers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Opposition parties nominated the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court today to head a caretaker government, the day after President H. M. Ershad announced his resignation.

docs.abstract: LEAD: When the Government of President H. M. Ershad made Islam the official religion of Bangladesh in June 1988, Hindus, Buddhists and Christians feared for their lives and property.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Government of President H. M. Ershad made Islam the official religion of Bangladesh in June 1988, Hindus, Buddhists and Christians feared for their lives and property.

headline.main: Official Islam Proving Gentler in Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: Official Islam Proving Gentler in Bangladesh

byline.original: By Barbara Crossette, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: As politicians struggle to fill the vacuum left by the abrupt resignation of President H. M. Ershad a week ago, many Bangladeshis say they fear that economic collapse and widespread civil strife may be unavoidable.    "The ports are not functioning, and we are going to run out of food in the countryside," a businessman said, placing the blame for the situation on Mr. Ershad, who encouraged imports of basic commodities rather than increasing local production.
docs.lead_paragraph: As politicians struggle to fill the vacuum left by the abrupt resignation of President H. M. Ershad a week ago, many Bangladeshis say they fear that economic collapse and widespread civil strife may be unavoidable.

headline.main: With Nation in Turmoil, Bangladeshis Fear Strife
headline.print_headline: With Nation in Turmoil, Bangladeshis Fear Strife

byline.original: By Barbara Crossette, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: President H. M. Ershad offered today to resign before presidential elections next year and to lift a state of emergency.   The 60-year-old former army general said on the state-run television that he was willing to resign 45 days before the election, which is scheduled for June. The opposition demanded that he step down immediately instead.
docs.lead_paragraph: President H. M. Ershad offered today to resign before presidential elections next year and to lift a state of emergency.

headline.main: Bangladesh Chief Offers Concession to Opposition
headline.print_headline: Bangladesh Chief Offers Concession to Opposition

docs.abstract: Military officers reported to be loyal to the deposed President, H. M. Ershad, were being moved out of their commands today as the army chief apparently sought to head off any armed intervention in politics, Bangladeshis close to the armed forces said.    In an atmosphere of increasing tension over the fate of Mr. Ershad, who seized power in a 1982 coup and ruled the country until being forced to resign on Dec. 5 under popular pressure, the American Ambassador to Bangladesh, William B. Milam, met today with the army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Mohammad Noor Uddin Khan.
docs.lead_paragraph: Military officers reported to be loyal to the deposed President, H. M. Ershad, were being moved out of their commands today as the army chief apparently sought to head off any armed intervention in politics, Bangladeshis close to the armed forces said.

headline.main: Bangladesh Army Chief Ousts Some Commanders
headline.print_headline: Bangladesh Army Chief Ousts Some Commanders

byline.original: By Barbara Crossette, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: The Government declared a state of emergency today after weeks of violence by opposition forces demanding that President H. M. Ershad resign.   Mr. Ershad said in a televised speech that the decree was necessary to safeguard the country's internal security in the face of what he called a conspiracy to destroy the economy.   The proclamation suspended all civil rights and imposed press censorship. An indefinite curfew was imposed on the capital, Dhaka, and the Government arrested a top opposition leader.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Government declared a state of emergency today after weeks of violence by opposition forces demanding that President H. M. Ershad resign.

headline.main: Citing Violence, Bangladesh Declares State of Emergency
headline.print_headline: Citing Violence, Bangladesh Declares State of Emergency
